H.title: Hydrogen
H.summary: Hydrogen is the lightest element and is usually found as diatomic H2 gas. It is central to acids, bases, and water chemistry.
properties: Nonmetal; colorless, odorless gas at room temperature.
Single valence electron enables covalent bonding and +1 oxidation states.
Very low density and high diffusivity.
applications: Feedstock for ammonia production and petroleum refining.
Used in fuel cells to generate electricity with water as the main byproduct.
H.safety: Hydrogen gas is highly flammable; avoid ignition sources and provide ventilation.

C.title: Carbon
C.summary: Carbon forms the backbone of organic chemistry and can bond in long chains and rings.
properties: Nonmetal with four valence electrons.
Forms strong covalent bonds and multiple allotropes (graphite, diamond).
Moderate electronegativity supports diverse bonding patterns.
applications: Essential in biological molecules and polymer materials.
Graphite is used in electrodes; diamond is used in cutting tools.

O.title: Oxygen
O.summary: Oxygen is a reactive nonmetal that supports combustion and is essential for aerobic life.
properties: Nonmetal with six valence electrons.
Common oxidation state is -2 in oxides and many ionic compounds.
Diatomic gas under standard conditions.
applications: Medical oxygen therapy and life support systems.
Industrial oxidizer for steelmaking and chemical synthesis.

Na.title: Sodium
Na.summary: Sodium is a soft alkali metal that reacts readily with water and forms +1 ions.
properties: Alkali metal with one valence electron.
Highly reactive and stored under oil to prevent oxidation.
Forms ionic compounds such as sodium chloride.
applications: Used in sodium-vapor lamps and as a heat-transfer medium in some reactors.
Sodium ions are essential for nerve signaling in biology.
Na.safety: Reacts violently with water; handle with dry equipment and inert storage.

Cl.title: Chlorine
Cl.summary: Chlorine is a reactive halogen that commonly forms -1 ions in salts.
properties: Halogen with seven valence electrons.
Diatomic gas with a strong oxidizing character.
Commonly found as chloride in seawater and minerals.
applications: Disinfection of drinking water and swimming pools.
Manufacture of PVC and other chlorinated materials.
Cl.safety: Chlorine gas is toxic and corrosive; use proper ventilation and protective gear.

Si.title: Silicon
Si.summary: Silicon is a metalloid with semiconducting behavior that powers modern electronics.
properties: Metalloid with four valence electrons.
Forms a tetrahedral network in crystalline silicon.
Oxidizes to SiO2, a major component of sand and glass.
applications: Semiconductor wafers for integrated circuits and solar cells.
Silica is used in glass, ceramics, and concrete.

Fe.title: Iron
Fe.summary: Iron is a transition metal with variable oxidation states and strong magnetic behavior.
properties: Common oxidation states include +2 and +3.
Partially filled d subshell enables complex formation and magnetism.
Forms alloys such as steel with enhanced strength.
applications: Structural steel for buildings, bridges, and tools.
Iron oxides are used as pigments and in magnetic materials.
